description: Brunei will restart in-school learning on June 2 for students who are sitting for public exams. Students in Year 6, 8, 10 Express, 11, 12 and 13 will be the first group to return to schools in the first phase of reopening, while other pupils will continue with online lessons. Teachers will conduct face-to-face learning from June 2-13 in the first phase of school reopening, after which the education ministry will decide whether to expand the number of returning students in the next phase.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Brunei will restart in-school learning on June 2 for students who are sitting for public exams. Students in Year 6, 8, 10 Express, 11, 12 and 13 will be the first group to return to schools in the first phase of reopening, while other pupils will continue with online lessons. Teachers will conduct face-to-face learning from June 2-13 in the first phase of school reopening, after which the education ministry will decide whether to expand the number of returning students in the next phase.

All students are still expected to continue e-learning despite starting in-school classes, with schools determining the number of virtual learning days.
 UPDATE: Year 7, 9, 10 and sixth form centre students will be the next group to return to public and private schools in the education ministry’s third phase of reopening. All students are still expected to continue e-learning despite starting in-school classes, with schools determining the number of virtual learning days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Body temperature screening are done for passengers arriving in Brunei Darussalam via the Brunei International Airport, especially from cities in China, starting 21 January 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: The Brunei government enforces entry restrictions for travellers coming from China from 30 January 2020.
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
From 30 January 2020, visitors from Hubei province or anyone with People’s Republic of China passport issued in Hubei will not be permitted to enter Brunei Darussalam. Anyone who has been in Hubei Province within 14 days before arriving in Brunei Darussalam will not be permitted to enter the country, with the exception of citizens and permanent residents of Brunei Darussalam.

Residents of Brunei Darussalam are prohibited from traveling to
Hubei Province and are advised from making non-essential travel
to China.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From 1 February 2020, travelers entering Brunei in all of its seven entry points will be subjected to temperature screening
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:

 UPDATE: Thermal screening are done at all entry points in Brunei from 1 February 2020.

description: On Saturday, February 15, Royal Brunei Airlines announced it is suspending flights to and from mainland China, and decreasing service to other Asian destinations due to decreased demand from the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak. Other impacted areas include Hong Kong, Indonesia, Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, and Vietnam. The decision is effective February 15 through Tuesday, March 31.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 4, 2020, the Brunei government warned nationals to avoid non-essential travel to mainland China, Italy, Islamic Republic of Iran, Republic of Korea, France, Germany, Hong Kong SAR (China), Japan, Singapore, Macao SAR (China), Malaysia (excluding Sabah, Sarawak and Labuan), Taiwan (China), Thailand, the United Kingdom, the United States of America, and Vietnam.

description:
From 11 February 2020, visitors from Hubei, Zhejiang and Jiangsu provinces are not permitted to enter Brunei Darussalam except citizens and permanent residents of Brunei Darussalam. Citizens are currently advised not to make any travel to Hubei, Zhejiang and Jiangsu provinces in the People’s Republic of China.

description: From 16 March 2020, all citizens and residents of Brunei Darussalam are restricted from leaving the country, except in certain circumstances such as undergoing urgent medical care, attending court hearings or resuming study abroad. Requests for permission to leave the country are subject to the approval of the Prime Minister's Office.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
From 17 March 2020, visitors who have been in Hubei province of
China, Republic of Iran and Europe (including United Kingdom) within the last 14 days before arriving in Brunei Darussalam are prohibited from entering Brunei. Citizens and permanent residents of Brunei Darussalam are exempted from this ban.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: From 17 March 2020, Brunei is enforcing a external border restriction where "foreign nationals who reside outside of Brunei Darussalam but commute by land to and from Brunei for work, or those who reside in the country but work outside of Brunei, and those who have applied / are applying for entry-and-exit permit from the Prime Minister’s Office, will only be granted entry for 1-month period, following which they can renew their application".
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: Starting from 5 March 2020, any visitors except citizen and permanent residents of Brunei Darussalam who has been in the Islamic Republic of Iran, Italy and Hubei, Jiangsu and Zhejiang province in China within 14 days of arriving in Brunei Darussalam are not allowed into this country including for transit purposes. UPDATE: Visitors who have been in Europe including United Kingdom in the last 14 days are not allowed to enter Brunei Darussalam after 17 March 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
From 23 March 2020, no foreign nationals will be allowed entry to
Brunei Darussalam whether by land, sea or air until further notice and this
prohibition includes foreign nationals entering the country for transit. However, special consideration will be given to those whose affairs are of national importance or pertain to the national interest of Brunei Darussalam. Any business that requires immigration clearance which
involves the transportation of basic necessities such as food, vegetables,
fish, medical supplies and similar, is exempt from the need to obtain
approval from the Department of Immigration and National Registration.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: In Brunei, Brunei and Malaysia-registered commercial transport operators including runners will be permitted to conduct cross-border delivery of goods and parcels from 6 May 2020. Transport operators are allowed carry out point-to-point delivery services but must return to their country of origin on the same day. Transport Operators registered in Brunei Darussalam must obtain approval prior to their duty travels from the Prime Minister’s Office.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description:
In Brunei, foreign nationals will be allowed to enter Brunei for essential travel from 15 September 2020 if an entry travel pass is granted and a  pre-departure COVID-19 Polymerase Chain Reaction (SARS-COV-2 RT-PCR) testing is done within 72 hours prior to departure at a designated medical center that is recognized by the government of the country of departure. The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the individuals with essential business travel (including official travel), students, individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment
or compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Education

description: Brunei is implementing a self isolation policy where "anyone who has been in China (except for foreign travelers from Hubei province who are not allowed to enter Brunei) within 14 days before arriving in Brunei Darussalam and permitted to enter the country will be required to undergo self-isolation for 14 days after 30 January 2020." Citizens or permanent residents of Brunei Darussalam who are in China (regardless of province) will be permitted to re-enter Brunei Darussalam and required to undergo self-isolation for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Brunei is implementing a self quarantine policy where "citizens, permanent residents and long-term visa holders of Brunei Darussalam who have been in all provinces of People’s Republic of China except Hubei, Zhejiang and Jiangsu provinces within 14 days before arriving in Brunei Darussalam are required to undergo self-isolation for 14 days on arrival" after February 11, 2020. 

Citizens or permanent residents of Brunei Darussalam who are in China (regardless of province) will be permitted to re-enter Brunei Darussalam. and required to self-isolate for 14 days

description: Brunei is enforcing a self-isolation policy where "any visitors arriving in the country via land or sea are required to undergo self-isolation for 14 days commencing from the date of their arrival in Brunei Darussalam" after 20 March 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Brunei is enforcing a self-isolation policy where "anyone (except foreign travelers who have been in Hubei province in People’s Republic of China Islamic Republic of Iran, Europe and United Kingdom in the past 14 days that are prohibited from entering Brunei) arriving from any country is required to undergo 14- days self-isolation upon arrival in Brunei Darussalam on March 17, 2020.
 UPDATE: The self-isolation policy has been changed such that all passengers arriving in Brunei Darussalam through Brunei International Airport are required to immediately undergo 14-days self-isolation at designated monitoring facilities.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Brunei is enforcing a self-isolation policy where "all passengers arriving in Brunei Darussalam via the Brunei International Airport can be considered to self-isolate at home if it has a separate room and preferably has its own toilet, there are no high risk individuals staying in the same premise, signs an agreement to comply with the rules stated in the Self-Isolation Notice, where they are required to stay in their own room and not allowed to leave their residence for 14 days and report in person to undergo a laboratory test for COVID-19 at the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha Hospital within 24-hours upon arrival" after 22 March 2020.

Any citizen or permanent resident of Brunei Darussalam who chooses to stay at The Empire Brunei to undergo their self-isolation have to pay a cost of $100 per day ($1,400 for 14 days).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: In Brunei, tracking bracelets named iMSafe have been issued by Ministry of Health to those who were ordered to undergo quarantine, alerting authorities when the device is taken off or if wearers break their COVID-19 quarantine. Earlier this month, they started distributing tracking wristbands to recovered coronavirus patients who are required to complete another 14 days of quarantine.

description: Citizens, permanent citizens of Brunei Darussalam are required to self- isolate at selected hotel accommodation for 2-14 days depending on the self-isolation notice that is given upon arrival as determined by the Ministry of Health after 15 September 2020. This policy also applies to foreign citizens who are allowed to enter Brunei (for individuals with essential business travel, students, individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment or for compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.)

description:
The Ministry of Health would like to further inform the public that starting tomorrow, Sunday, 5 April 2020, all individuals arriving in Brunei Darussalam will be required to undergo self-isolation in facilities provided by the Government and will no longer be allowed to undergo self-isolation in their own home.
 UPDATE: Citizens, permanent residents of Brunei Darussalam and foreign residents who are allowed to enter Brunei are required to self-isolate between 2-14 days depending on self-isolation notice given on arrival after 15 September 2020.

description:
Brunei: gyms, fitness centres, indoor and outdoor sports facilities are now permitted to operate at 60 percent capacity from 15 June, each user must make advance bookings at gyms and sports facilities as well as download the BruHealth application for QR code registration.

Gyms, fitness centers, indoor sports facilities and outdoor sports facilities will now be allowed to operate at 90 percent (July 6) capacity from the previous 60 percent

description:
Brunei government will reopen senior citizen centres, museums, exhibition galleries and libraries on June 15.

For museums, exhibition galleries and libraries, group activities are allowed but limited to 30 people depending on the size of the venue. Outdoor activities are still banned.

The public facilities, which have been closed for nearly three months, will be open for three days a week for five hours.

Museums, public exhibition galleries and libraries will open every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday while private exhibition gallery owners will decide their opening hours.

description:
From 5 June to 17 June 2020, churches and temples in Brunei are 
allowed to operate for public service for 2 hours on Sunday and one day 
per week respectively. Other places of worship other than mosques and 
surau are allowed to operate at 30% of normal capacity at any one time. The management of places of worship other than mosques and surau are required to obtain BruHealth QR code specific for their premise and print out the QR code and place it at the entrance so that it can be scanned by visitors before entering and upon leaving the premise. The management of places of worship other than mosques and surau are required to ensure cleanliness and physical distancing measures.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: After 15 June 2020, mosques, surau and prayer halls in Brunei will reopen for the five daily prayers, in addition to Friday prayers. Temperature checks before entering the mosque will be implemented and each jamaah are advised to use face masks, as well as to bring their own prayer mat and to sanitize their hands before entering the mosque. Women and children under the age of 15 years old are still restricted to attend Friday Prayers but they are allowed to participate in the Five daily prayers. Social and physical distancing, using the BruHealth App and scanning the QR Code are implemented too.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
In Brunei, mosques, suraus, and other religious halls will reopen for Friday prayers from May 29 with safeguards in place. Precautions include requiring visitors to use the contact tracing application and limiting entry to men above 15 years old. Individuals caught breaching regulations could face a BND 10,000 (USD 7,100) fine and six months' imprisonment.
 UPDATE: Mosques, surau and prayer halls will reopen for the five daily prayers, in addition to Friday prayers after 15 June 2020
